info.long_name: Median percentage of 3rd graders passing reading test
info.short_description: Median percentage of 3rd grade population passing reading test for schools in the region
info.long_description: Median percentage of 3rd grade population passing reading test. The median is calculated across schools in the region.
info.statement: On average, {value} of 3rd graders pass reading in {region_name}.

sources.name: Virginia Department of Education
sources.location: Data & Reports > Statistics & Reports > SOL Test Pass Rates & Other Results

info.long_name: Percentage civilian employed
info.short_description: Population self-reported as employed as a percentage of total civilian workforce population.
info.long_description: Population self-reported as employed as a percentage of total civilian workforce population. Based on American Community Survey Table B23025 ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.
info.statement: {value} of the population in {features.name} is employed.

info.long_name: Day Care Capacity
info.short_description: Summed capacity (seats) of all day care providers within the region.
info.long_description: Summed capacity (seats) of all day care providers within the region.
info.statement: There are {value} daycare seats in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Minutes to Nearest Day Care
info.short_description: Time (minutes) to drive to the nearest day care provider.
info.long_description: Time (minutes) to drive to the nearest day care provider of any type.
info.statement: It takes {value} to drive to the nearest day care provider in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 15
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 15 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Ages 5 to 14
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population 5 and 14 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 10
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 10 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: 2-year schools per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

info.long_name: drive time to nearest 2-year school
info.short_description: Drive time to the nearest 2-year schools.
info.long_description: Minimal drive time to a school authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates from the Census block group centroid, as calculated by the Open Source Routing Machine in 2022. School locations are from the National Center for Education Statistics. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.
info.statement: It takes {value} to drive to a 2-year school from {region_name}'s block group centroids on average.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

info.long_name: Dental care geographic availability (2 step-enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of dental care availability based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description: Dental care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of dentists per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for dentists (population served by dentists). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The dental care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.short_description: Median drive time (minutes) to the ten closest emergency medical services facilities
info.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest emergency medical services facilities. Facility location data was collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository. Drive times were computed using Open Source Routing Machine (Using roads for year 2021).
info.statement: The median drive time to the ten closest emergency medical service facilities to {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Emergency medical services access score (3-step floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of emergency medical services accessibility based on supply and demand of facilities
info.long_description: Emergency medical services access score based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
info.statement: The emergency medical services accessibility score for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_description: Count of emergency medical services facilities based on facility locations. Location data was collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository.
info.statement: There are {value} emergency medical services facilities in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure children
info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.long_name: Average meal cost ($)
info.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
info.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
info.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure
info.short_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods.

Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.

info.long_name: Hospital beds per 100k people
info.short_description: Number of hospital beds per 100k people.
info.long_description: Number of hospital beds per 100k people, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) hospitals as listed by the U.S. Health and Human Services, with number of beds (overall average of 7 day averages) as supply values, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the total population as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distance between hospital locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} hospital beds per 100k people in {features.name}.

sources.name: U.S. Department of Health & Human Services
sources.location: Hospital > COVID-19 Reported Patient Impact and Hospital Capacity by Facility

info.short_description: Time (minutes) to drive to the nearest day care provider.
info.long_description: Time (minutes) to drive to the nearest day care provider of any type.
info.statement: It takes {value} to drive to the nearest day care provider in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 15
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 15 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Ages 5 to 14
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population 5 and 14 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 10
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 10 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: 2-year schools per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

info.long_name: drive time to nearest 2-year school
info.short_description: Drive time to the nearest 2-year schools.
info.long_description: Minimal drive time to a school authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates from the Census block group centroid, as calculated by the Open Source Routing Machine in 2022. School locations are from the National Center for Education Statistics. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.
info.statement: It takes {value} to drive to a 2-year school from {region_name}'s block group centroids on average.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

info.long_name: <2-year schools per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of <2-year schools per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award certificates that are typically obtained in less than 2 years per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) <2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} <2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

info.long_name: drive time to nearest <2-year school
info.short_description: Drive time to the nearest <2-year schools.
info.long_description: Minimal drive time to a schools authorized to award certificates that are typically obtained in less than 2 years from the Census block group centroid, as calculated by the Open Source Routing Machine in 2022. School locations are from the National Center for Education Statistics. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.
info.statement: It takes {value} to drive to a <2-year school from {region_name}'s block group centroids on average.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

info.long_name: 2-year biomedical programs per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools with biomedical programs per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or less than 2-year or longer certificates with biomedical programs (any with Classification of Institutional Programs [CIP] codes starting with 26) per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools with any degrees conferred in the given year with a CIP code starting with 26, as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools with a biomedical program per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics and Completions files

info.long_name: Dental care geographic availability (2 step-enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of dental care availability based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description: Dental care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of dentists per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for dentists (population served by dentists). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The dental care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest emergency medical services facilities. info.long_name: Emergency medical services access score (3-step floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of emergency medical services accessibility based on supply and demand of facilities
info.long_description: Emergency medical services access score based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
info.statement: The emergency medical services accessibility score for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure children
info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.long_name: Average meal cost ($)
info.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
info.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
info.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Hospital beds per 100k people
info.short_description: Number of hospital beds per 100k people.
info.long_description: Number of hospital beds per 100k people, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) hospitals as listed by the U.S. Health and Human Services, with number of beds (overall average of 7 day averages) as supply values, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the total population as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distance between hospital locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} hospital beds per 100k people in {features.name}.

sources.name: U.S. Department of Health & Human Services
sources.location: Hospital > COVID-19 Reported Patient Impact and Hospital Capacity by Facility

info.statement: The pediatric care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 15
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 15 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Ages 5 to 14
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age.

Catchment area ratios are based on population 5 and 14 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 10
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: 2-year schools per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

info.statement: It takes {value} to drive to a 2-year school from {region_name}'s block group centroids on average.

info.short_description: Index of dental care availability based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description: Dental care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of dentists per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for dentists (population served by dentists). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The dental care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure children
info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.long_name: Average meal cost ($)
info.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
info.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
info.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure
info.short_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods.
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population in {features.name} are food insecure.

Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. info.long_name: Hospital beds per 100k people
info.short_description: Number of hospital beds per 100k people.
info.long_description: Number of hospital beds per 100k people, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) hospitals as listed by the U.S. Health and Human Services, with number of beds (overall average of 7 day averages) as supply values, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the total population as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distance between hospital locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} hospital beds per 100k people in {features.name}.

sources.name: U.S. Department of Health & Human Services
sources.location: Hospital > COVID-19 Reported Patient Impact and Hospital Capacity by Facility

info.long_name: Intensive care unit beds per 100k people

info.long_description: Number of Intensive care unit beds per 100k people, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) hospitals with intensive care unit beds as listed by the U.S. Health and Human Services, with number of intensive care unit beds (overall average of 7 day averages) as supply values, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the total population as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distance between hospital locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} intensive care unit beds per 100k people in {features.name}.

sources.name: U.S. Department of Health & Human Services

info.long_description: Primary care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. info.statement: The primary care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 15
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 15 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Ages 5 to 14

Catchment area ratios are based on population 5 and 14 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: 2-year schools per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure children
info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.long_name: Average meal cost ($)
info.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
info.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
info.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure
info.short_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods.
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. info.long_name: Hospital beds per 100k people
info.short_description: Number of hospital beds per 100k people.
info.long_description: Number of hospital beds per 100k people, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) hospitals as listed by the U.S. Health and Human Services, with number of beds (overall average of 7 day averages) as supply values, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the total population as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distance between hospital locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} hospital beds per 100k people in {features.name}.

sources.name: U.S. Department of Health & Human Services
sources.location: Hospital > COVID-19 Reported Patient Impact and Hospital Capacity by Facility

info.long_name: Intensive care unit beds per 100k people
info.short_description: Number of Intensive care unit beds per 100k people.
info.long_description: Number of Intensive care unit beds per 100k people, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) hospitals with intensive care unit beds as listed by the U.S. Health and Human Services, with number of intensive care unit beds (overall average of 7 day averages) as supply values, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the total population as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distance between hospital locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} intensive care unit beds per 100k people in {features.name}.

sources.name: U.S. Department of Health & Human Services
sources.location: Hospital > COVID-19 Reported Patient Impact and Hospital Capacity by Facility

info.statement: There are {value} children's hospital beds per 100k people in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Mental health services access by median drive time to the ten closest facilities in minutes
info.short_description: Median drive time (minutes) to the ten closest mental health services facilities
info.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest mental health services facilities. Facility location data was collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository. Drive times were computed using Open Source Routing Machine (Using roads for year 2021).
info.statement: The median drive time to the ten closest mental health service facilities to {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Mental health services access score (3-step  floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of mental health services accessibility based on supply and demand of facilities
info.long_description: Mental health services access score based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
info.statement: The mental health services accessibility score for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Access to mental health services by count
info.short_description: Count of mental health facilities based on facility locations
info.long_description: Count of mental health facilities based on facility locations. Location data was collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository.
info.statement: There are {value} mental health facilities in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Retail food environment index
info.short_description: The number of available healthy and less healthy food retailers. A higher score indicates more available healthy options per less healthy options. A score of 0 indicates available no options (food desert).
info.statement: The Retail food environment index is {value} in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Percentage of population with health insurance
info.short_description: Percentage of the population (ages 19-64) self-reported to be currently covered by any type of health insurance or health coverage plan
info.long_description: Percentage of the population self-reported to be currently covered by any type of health insurance or health coverage plan. Based on American Community Survey Table B27010 in ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.
info.statement: {value} of the population has health insurance in {features.name}.

info.long_name: OBGYN care geographic availability (2-step enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of OBGYN care availability based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description: OBGYN care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of OBGYNs per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for OBGYNs (population served by OBGYNs). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online physician directory.
info.statement: The OBGYN availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Pediatric care geographic availability (2-step enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of pediatric care physician availability based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description: Pediatric care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of pediatricians per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for pediatricians (population under 16). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The pediatric care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 15
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 15 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Ages 5 to 14
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population 5 and 14 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 10
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: 2-year schools per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

School locations are from the National Center for Education Statistics. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.
info.statement: It takes {value} to drive to a 2-year school from {region_name}'s block group centroids on average.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure children
info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.long_name: Average meal cost ($)
info.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
info.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
info.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Hospital beds per 100k people
info.short_description: Number of hospital beds per 100k people.
info.long_description: Number of hospital beds per 100k people, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) hospitals as listed by the U.S. Health and Human Services, with number of beds (overall average of 7 day averages) as supply values, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the total population as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distance between hospital locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} hospital beds per 100k people in {features.name}.

sources.location: Hospital > COVID-19 Reported Patient Impact and Hospital Capacity by Facility

info.short_description: Median drive time (minutes) to the ten closest mental health services facilities
info.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest mental health services facilities. Facility location data was collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository. Drive times were computed using Open Source Routing Machine (Using roads for year 2021).
info.statement: The median drive time to the ten closest mental health service facilities to {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Mental health services access score (3-step  floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of mental health services accessibility based on supply and demand of facilities
info.long_description: Mental health services access score based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
info.statement: The mental health services accessibility score for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Access to mental health services by count
info.short_description: Count of mental health facilities based on facility locations
info.long_description: Count of mental health facilities based on facility locations. Location data was collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository.
info.statement: There are {value} mental health facilities in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Retail food environment index
info.short_description: The number of available healthy and less healthy food retailers. A higher score indicates more available healthy options per less healthy options. A score of 0 indicates available no options (food desert).
info.statement: The Retail food environment index is {value} in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Percentage of population with health insurance
info.short_description: Percentage of the population (ages 19-64) self-reported to be currently covered by any type of health insurance or health coverage plan
info.long_description: Percentage of the population self-reported to be currently covered by any type of health insurance or health coverage plan. Based on American Community Survey Table B27010 in ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.
info.statement: {value} of the population has health insurance in {features.name}.

info.long_name: OBGYN care geographic availability (2-step enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of OBGYN care availability based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description: OBGYN care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of OBGYNs per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for OBGYNs (population served by OBGYNs). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online physician directory.
info.statement: The OBGYN availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Pediatric care geographic availability (2-step enhanced floating catchment areas)

This method is an aggregation of pediatricians per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for pediatricians (population under 16). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The pediatric care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Median percentage of 3rd graders passing reading test
info.short_description: Median percentage of 3rd grade population passing reading test for schools in the region
info.long_description: Median percentage of 3rd grade population passing reading test. The median is calculated across schools in the region.
info.statement: On average, {value} of 3rd graders pass reading in {region_name}.

sources.name: Virginia Department of Education
sources.location: Data & Reports > Statistics & Reports > SOL Test Pass Rates & Other Results

info.long_name: Percentage civilian employed
info.short_description: Population self-reported as employed as a percentage of total civilian workforce population.
info.long_description: Population self-reported as employed as a percentage of total civilian workforce population. Based on American Community Survey Table B23025 ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates.
info.statement: {value} of the population in {features.name} is employed.

info.long_name: Day Care Capacity
info.short_description: Summed capacity (seats) of all day care providers within the region.
info.long_description: Summed capacity (seats) of all day care providers within the region.
info.statement: There are {value} daycare seats in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Minutes to Nearest Day Care
info.short_description: Time (minutes) to drive to the nearest day care provider.
info.long_description: Time (minutes) to drive to the nearest day care provider of any type.
info.statement: It takes {value} to drive to the nearest day care provider in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 15
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 15 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Ages 5 to 14
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population 5 and 14 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 10
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 10 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: 2-year schools per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

info.long_name: drive time to nearest 2-year school
info.short_description: Drive time to the nearest 2-year schools.
info.long_description: Minimal drive time to a school authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates from the Census block group centroid, as calculated by the Open Source Routing Machine in 2022. School locations are from the National Center for Education Statistics. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.
info.statement: It takes {value} to drive to a 2-year school from {region_name}'s block group centroids on average.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

info.long_name: 2-year biomedical programs per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools with biomedical programs per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or less than 2-year or longer certificates with biomedical programs (any with Classification of Institutional Programs [CIP] codes starting with 26) per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools with any degrees conferred in the given year with a CIP code starting with 26, as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools with a biomedical program per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics and Completions files

info.long_name: Dental care geographic availability (2 step-enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of dental care availability based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description: Dental care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of dentists per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for dentists (population served by dentists). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The dental care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Emergency medical services access by median drive time to the ten closest facilities in minutes
info.short_description: Median drive time (minutes) to the ten closest emergency medical services facilities
info.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest emergency medical services facilities. Facility location data was collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository. Drive times were computed using Open Source Routing Machine (Using roads for year 2021).
info.statement: The median drive time to the ten closest emergency medical service facilities to {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Emergency medical services access score (3-step floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of emergency medical services accessibility based on supply and demand of facilities
info.long_description: Emergency medical services access score based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
info.statement: The emergency medical services accessibility score for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Access to emergency medical services by count
info.short_description: Count of emergency medical services facilities based on facility locations
info.long_description: Count of emergency medical services facilities based on facility locations. Location data was collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository.
info.statement: There are {value} emergency medical services facilities in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure children
info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.long_name: Average meal cost ($)
info.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
info.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
info.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure
info.short_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods.
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.long_name: Count of food insecure children
info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: The population of food insecure children in {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Hospital beds per 100k people
info.short_description: Number of hospital beds per 100k people.
info.long_description: Number of hospital beds per 100k people, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) hospitals as listed by the U.S. Health and Human Services, with number of beds (overall average of 7 day averages) as supply values, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the total population as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distance between hospital locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} hospital beds per 100k people in {features.name}.

sources.name: U.S. Department of Health & Human Services
sources.location: Hospital > COVID-19 Reported Patient Impact and Hospital Capacity by Facility

info.long_name: Minutes to Nearest Day Care
info.short_description: Time (minutes) to drive to the nearest day care provider.
info.long_description: Time (minutes) to drive to the nearest day care provider of any type.
info.statement: It takes {value} to drive to the nearest day care provider in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 15
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 15 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Ages 5 to 14
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population 5 and 14 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 10
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 10 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: 2-year schools per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

info.long_name: drive time to nearest 2-year school
info.short_description: Drive time to the nearest 2-year schools.
info.long_description: Minimal drive time to a school authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates from the Census block group centroid, as calculated by the Open Source Routing Machine in 2022. School locations are from the National Center for Education Statistics. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.
info.statement: It takes {value} to drive to a 2-year school from {region_name}'s block group centroids on average.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

info.long_name: <2-year schools per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of <2-year schools per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award certificates that are typically obtained in less than 2 years per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) <2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} <2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

info.long_name: drive time to nearest <2-year school
info.short_description: Drive time to the nearest <2-year schools.
info.long_description: Minimal drive time to a schools authorized to award certificates that are typically obtained in less than 2 years from the Census block group centroid, as calculated by the Open Source Routing Machine in 2022. School locations are from the National Center for Education Statistics. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.
info.statement: It takes {value} to drive to a <2-year school from {region_name}'s block group centroids on average.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

info.long_name: Dental care geographic availability (2 step-enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of dental care availability based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description: Dental care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of dentists per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for dentists (population served by dentists). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The dental care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest emergency medical services facilities. info.long_name: Emergency medical services access score (3-step floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of emergency medical services accessibility based on supply and demand of facilities
info.long_description: Emergency medical services access score based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
info.statement: The emergency medical services accessibility score for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_description: Count of emergency medical services facilities based on facility locations. Location data was collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository.
info.statement: There are {value} emergency medical services facilities in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure children
info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.long_name: Average meal cost ($)
info.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
info.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
info.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure

info.long_name: Hospital beds per 100k people
info.short_description: Number of hospital beds per 100k people.
info.long_description: Number of hospital beds per 100k people, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) hospitals as listed by the U.S. Health and Human Services, with number of beds (overall average of 7 day averages) as supply values, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the total population as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distance between hospital locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} hospital beds per 100k people in {features.name}.

sources.name: U.S. Department of Health & Human Services
sources.location: Hospital > COVID-19 Reported Patient Impact and Hospital Capacity by Facility
