info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 15
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 15 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Ages 5 to 14
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population 5 and 14 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children between 5 and 14 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: Day Care Seats Per 1k Children Under 10
info.short_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age.
info.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 years of age, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on population under 10 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), day care capacity (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer.
info.statement: There are {value} day care seats per 1,000 children under 10 in {region_name}.

info.long_name: 2-year schools per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

info.statement: It takes {value} to drive to a 2-year school from {region_name}'s block group centroids on average.

info.long_name: 2-year science programs per 100k people over 14
info.short_description: Number of 2-year schools with science programs per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.
info.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or less than 2-year or longer certificates with science programs (any with Classification of Institutional Programs [CIP] codes starting with 41) per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) 2-year schools with any degrees conferred in the given year with a CIP code starting with 41, as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools with a science program per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics and Completions files

info.long_name: Dental care geographic availability (2 step-enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of dental care availability based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description: Dental care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of dentists per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for dentists (population served by dentists). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The dental care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Emergency medical services access by median drive time to the ten closest facilities in minutes
info.short_description: Median drive time (minutes) to the ten closest emergency medical services facilities
info.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest emergency medical services facilities. Facility location data was collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository. Drive times were computed using Open Source Routing Machine (Using roads for year 2021).
info.statement: The median drive time to the ten closest emergency medical service facilities to {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Emergency medical services access score (3-step floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of emergency medical services accessibility based on supply and demand of facilities
info.long_description: Emergency medical services access score based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
info.statement: The emergency medical services accessibility score for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Access to emergency medical services by count
info.short_description: Count of emergency medical services facilities based on facility locations
info.long_description: Count of emergency medical services facilities based on facility locations. Location data was collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository.
info.statement: There are {value} emergency medical services facilities in {features.name}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure children
info.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
info.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

info.long_name: Average meal cost ($)
info.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
info.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
info.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_name: Percentage of food insecure
info.short_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods.
info.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.

info.long_name: Hospital beds per 100k people
info.short_description: Number of hospital beds per 100k people.
info.long_description: Number of hospital beds per 100k people, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) hospitals as listed by the U.S. Health and Human Services, with number of beds (overall average of 7 day averages) as supply values, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the total population as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distance between hospital locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} hospital beds per 100k people in {features.name}.

sources.name: U.S. Department of Health & Human Services
sources.location: Hospital > COVID-19 Reported Patient Impact and Hospital Capacity by Facility

info.long_name: Intensive care unit beds per 100k people
info.short_description: Number of Intensive care unit beds per 100k people.
info.long_description: Number of Intensive care unit beds per 100k people, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) hospitals with intensive care unit beds as listed by the U.S. Health and Human Services, with number of intensive care unit beds (overall average of 7 day averages) as supply values, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the total population as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distance between hospital locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
info.statement: There are {value} intensive care unit beds per 100k people in {features.name}.

sources.name: U.S. Department of Health & Human Services
sources.location: Hospital > COVID-19 Reported Patient Impact and Hospital Capacity by Facility

info.long_name: Preventable hospital stays per 100,000 Medicare enrollees
info.short_description: Rate of hospital stays for ambulatory-care sensitive conditions per 100,000 Medicare enrollees
info.long_description: Rate of hospital stays for ambulatory-care sensitive conditions per 100,000 Medicare enrollees. Ambulatory care refers to diagnoses that are usually treatable in outpatient settings. Data are based on Medicare claims and come from County Health Rankings.
info.statement: {value} of the hospitalizations in {features.name} were preventable (due to conditions usually treated in outpatient settings).

info.long_name: Primary care geographic availability (2-step enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of primary care physician availability based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description: Primary care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of physicians per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for physicians (population served by physicians). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: The primary care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

info.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest substance use/behavioral health services facilities. info.long_description: Substance use/behavioral health services access score based on 3-step  floating catchment areas.
